The commentary states: Vastness immediately enters into the uninterrupted, dust and hair encompass and contain without outside. This is the second gate of unobstructed freedom in vastness and narrowness.

The upper sentence says the large can enter the small, and the lower sentence says the small can accommodate the large. Although there is immediate entry, the meaning is to take vastness and narrowness.
Uninterrupted means small. When it is small, there is no inside, and because there is no inside, there is no middle.
Without outside means large. When it is large, there is no outside.
Without outside is precisely the vast body and realm, which immediately enter the dust and hair without inside. Therefore, it is called the unobstructed vastness and narrowness.
Whether it is identical or entering, both achieve the unobstructed vastness and narrowness.
The sutra says: The number of vajra-encircling mountains is immeasurable, and they can all be placed on the tip of a single hair.
If you want to know that the greatest has a small appearance, the bodhisattva begins to generate this mind because of this.
The greatest has a small appearance, which is precisely the unobstructed vastness and narrowness.
It also says, One can make a small world into a large world, and a large world into a small world, and so on.
The commentary states, Clearly appearing simultaneously, like a mustard seed in a vase, which refers to the third gate of subtle mutual containment and establishment.
One is able to contain many, which is called mutual containment.
One and many are not mixed, so it is called establishment.
Bing means bright.
There are three kinds of subtlety:
First, the subtlety of what is contained.

It is like a lapis lazuli vase containing many mustard seeds, clearly appearing simultaneously without obstruction, neither before nor after. This is explained in the Sutra of the Inconceivable Realm of the Tathagata.
However, there are two versions:
One version says white mustard seeds;
One version simply says mustard seeds, and now I follow this version.
It means that one dharma accords with the nature and contains everything, so all dharmas are present in one according to the contained principle.
It is also the unobstructed and sovereign real virtue of dependent origination, causing the mutual containment, not created by gods or humans, and thus can be established.
As in the eight aspects, each aspect contains the eight aspects, called subtle.
Second, concerning the subtlety of being able to contain.
Third, concerning the subtlety of being difficult to know.
The commentary states: The complete and simultaneous ocean drop is the fourth gate of simultaneous completeness and correspondence.
Like a single drop of the great ocean, it already contains the flavors of the hundred rivers and the ten virtues. Therefore, each and every dharma encompasses inexhaustible dharmas.
And the following nine gates take this one gate as their general principle, so they are simultaneously clarified without priority or posteriority, and the complete inclusion is without omission.

As for the ten virtues, the DaÅ›abhÅ«mika-sÅ«tra says: First, they gradually deepen; second, they do not harbor dead bodies; third, other waters that enter lose their original names; fourth, they are all of the same taste; fifth, they are replete with innumerable precious treasures; sixth, they are deep and difficult to fathom; seventh, they are vast and immeasurable; eighth, they are the abode of great beings; ninth, the tides do not go beyond their limits; tenth, they universally accept great rains.
The Nirvana Sutra says: It is like a person who enters the great ocean to bathe, then uses the waters of all the rivers.
Cultivating in accordance with this, the virtues within a single practice are inexhaustible.
The commentary states: The unobstructed interpenetration of one and many, like a thousand lamps in an empty room, is the fifth gate of the mutual containment of one and many.

Because one and many mutually serve as causes and conditions for each other, their powers and functions interpenetrate, thus they are able to mutually enter each other, which is called mutual containment.
Without destroying their characteristics, therefore it is said to be not the same.
It is like a thousand lamps illuminating a single room. The lamps differ according to the vessels, each being different;
The lamps pervade according to the light, with each light interpenetrating, always separate and always entering.
The sutra says, Understanding the immeasurable within the one, and understanding the one within the immeasurable.
Understanding their mutual arising, one will attain fearlessness.
This lamp metaphor can also illustrate the mutual identity of the one and the many.
When looking directly at the light, one does not see separate appearances, because there is only a single light.
The commentary states, Concealment and revelation are both accomplished, like a sliver of moon in an autumn sky. This is the sixth gate of secret concealment and revelation.

It is like the moon on the eighth or ninth night, half concealed and half revealed. When it is fully revealed, it is concealed; when it is fully concealed, it is revealed. It is not like the dark moon when it is concealed without revelation, nor like the full moon when it is revealed without concealment.ğŸ”½When the one subsumes the many, then the one is revealed and the many are concealed;
When the many subsume the one, then the many are revealed and the one is concealed.
When a single hair subsumes the Dharma realm, then the Dharma realms of the other hairs are all concealed.
The remaining hairs mutually include each other, and the hidden and revealed are also like this.
However, the half-month is not only when brightness and darkness are together, but also below the brightness there is darkness, and below the darkness there is brightness.
If in the east one enters right concentration, it is half brightness;
in the west, rising from concentration, it is half darkness.ğŸ”½The place of entering in the east is the place of rising in the east, like there being darkness below brightness;
the place of rising in the west is the place of entering in the west, like there being brightness below darkness.
Therefore it is called the secret hidden and revealed simultaneously accomplished gate.
The text says, The layers upon layers of reflections are like the hanging pearls of the Indra net, which is the seventh Indra net realm gate.

It is like the pearl net covering above the palace of Indra, in one bright pearl all the myriad images appear together in all the pearls, and yet they mutually reflect each other, with reflections within reflections, layer upon layer without end.
Although the light and colors are many and intermingled, they are still distinct, like two mirrors reflecting each other, interpenetrating, transmitting light and reflecting each other, endlessly.
The commentary states: Moment after moment, perfectly interfused, like a dream passing through a lifetime, is the eighth gate of the distinct dharmas of the ten directions.

This is the Chapter on Leaving the World, where the bodhisattvas have ten ways of speaking about the three times, namely: speaking of the past in the past, speaking of the present in the past, speaking of the future in the past, speaking of the past in the present, speaking of equality in the present, speaking of the future in the present, speaking of the past in the future, speaking of the present in the future, speaking of the inexhaustible in the future, and speaking of a single thought in the three times.
The first nine are specific, and a single thought is the general, so it is called the ten times, because the three times are mutually dependent and mutually inclusive.
A single thought has ten to show its inexhaustibility, so a single thought is immeasurable eons, and immeasurable eons are a single thought.
The Samantabhadra Practice Chapter says, Immeasurable and innumerable kalpas are understood to be a single thought.
Knowing that thought is also non-thought, thus one sees the world.
Like a dream in a single night, passing through many kalpas.
The MahÄyÄnasaá¹ƒgraha says, Dreaming of spending a year, it is only a moment upon awakening.
Therefore, although time is immeasurable, it is contained in a single instant.
The Chapter on Leaving the World says, Like a person in a dream creating various things, even if it lasts for billions of years, it has not yet ended in a single night.
Therefore, Zhuangzi dreamed of being a butterfly, and falsely slept for a hundred years.
Such events are numerous.
The commentary says, The Dharma gates are layered like clouds rising in the vast sky, which is the ninth gate of manifesting understanding by revealing the Dharma through events.
The meaning of layered is to show that one and many do not obstruct each other, so each event has many Dharma gates.
Because each and every phenomenon is the inexhaustible Dharma realm, and since the Dharma realm is inexhaustible, phenomena are also inexhaustible.

The chapter on dedication states, These flowers arise from the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas, and so forth. The meaning clarifies that all causes give rise to a single effect, and that single effect is endowed with all causes. Therefore, it is not that this relies on something else to be manifested.
The commentary states, The myriad practices are scattered, like flowers opening on brocade, which refers to the tenth gate of the perfect interfusion of the various treasuries.
This name appears in the ten mysteries of the ultimate reality. However, there are two meanings, so Chengguan changed it to the gate of the unimpeded freedom of vastness and minuteness.

First, if being in accord with principle is considered pure and myriad practices are considered mixed, then this is the non-obstruction of phenomena and principle, not the non-obstruction of phenomena and phenomena.
Even if the great compassion of bodhisattvas is considered pure, exhausting the future to only see the practice of compassion, the other practices are like empty space.
If it is about the miscellaneous gate, then the two gates are different when cultivating myriad practices together, and it also does not form unobstructed interpenetration of all phenomena.
Second, like in the gate of giving, all myriad dharmas are all called giving, so it is called pure.
And this gate of giving is endowed with the practices of the perfections, so it is called miscellaneous.
In this way, the pure and the miscellaneous do not obstruct each other, so it is called endowed with virtues, and then the meaning of unobstructed interpenetration of all phenomena is accomplished.
And moreover, the perfections are contained within one, so the perfections abiding is called the gate of entry by characteristics;
If the perfections are extinguished, it again resembles the gate of entry by identity.
Therefore, it is not preserved, and is changed to broad and narrow.
Now, the ultimate characteristic only takes practice as a small difference. This section is generally without the host and retinue, so it is again brought out to form ten meanings.
As for the comparison of flowers blooming on brocade, the meaning takes the five-colored thread. Although the colors of the flowers are different, each thread passes through all of them.
Permeation is likened to purity, and differentiation is likened to mixture, thus permanence, universality, and differentiation are called unobstructed.
It is not the same as embroidery and painting, which are only different, and does not extend to the ten mysteries above.
It briefly presents the general framework, and in detail it is as explained in the section on the scope of meaning below.
As for the high that cannot be looked up to, then the bodhisattvas of accumulated practices expose their gills and scales at the Dragon Gate - the seventh is the sudden transcendence of benefits.
The text has ten meanings.
The first two meanings generally show the high and profound, clarifying that the provisional and small cannot fathom it;

Moreover, the first two high and profound meanings, by contrast, clarify the completion of benefits, showing that the provisional and small cannot fathom it, because in the past there was no cause, and by contrast it encourages sentient beings to have faith and understanding;
The last eight directly show the completion of benefits, namely, being able to be sudden and perfect, and causing them to definitely accept it.
Now, the first is the first, clarifying the distance.

If Mount Tai leans against the heavens and Mount Emei brushes the Han, it is difficult to look up to its peak. Therefore, the Analects says, The higher you look up to it, the higher it is; the more you drill into it, the firmer it is.
